description: From Middle English hete, from Old English hǣtu, from Proto-West Germanic *haitī, from Proto-Germanic *haitį̄ (“heat”), from Proto-Indo-European *kayd-, a derived form of *kay- (“heat; hot”).

Cognate with Scots hete (“heat”), North Frisian hiet (“heat”), Old High German heizī (“heat”). Related also to Dutch hitte (“heat”), German Hitze (“heat”), Swedish hetta (“heat”), Icelandic hiti (“heat”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Thermal energy.
examples: Heat and temperature, although different, are intimately related. [...] For example, suppose you added equal amounts of heat to equal masses of iron and aluminum. How do you think their temperatures would change? […] if the temperature of the iron increased by 100 C°, the corresponding temperature change in the aluminum would be only 48 C°.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The condition or quality of being hot.
examples: Stay out of the heat of the sun!

entries.meaning: (uncountable) An attribute of a spice that causes a burning sensation in the mouth.
examples: The chili sauce gave the dish heat.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A period of intensity, particularly of emotion.
examples: It's easy to make bad decisions in the heat of the moment.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) An undesirable amount of attention.
examples: The heat from her family after her DUI arrest was unbearable.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, slang) The police.
(uncountable, slang) One or more firearms.
(countable, baseball) A fastball.
examples: The catcher called for the heat, high and tight.

definitionGroups.group: (uncountable) A condition where a mammal is aroused sexually or where it is especially fertile and therefore eager to mate; oestrus.

entries.meaning: (countable, fandom slang) In omegaverse fiction, a cyclical period in which omegas experience an intense, sometimes irresistible biological urge to mate.
examples: Some stories engage in dub-con scenarios where one or both partners are out of their minds with heat lust and lose all reasoning and inhibitions.

entries.meaning: (countable) A preliminary race, used to determine the participants in a final race
examples: The runner had high hopes, but was out of contention after the first heat.

entries.meaning: (countable, by extension) A stage in a competition, not necessarily a sporting one; a round.
(countable) One cycle of bringing metal to maximum temperature and working it until it is too cool to work further.
examples: I can make a scroll like that in a single heat.

entries.meaning: (countable) A hot spell.
examples: The children stayed indoors during this year's summer heat.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Heating system; a system that raises the temperature of a room or building.
examples: I'm freezing; could you turn on the heat?

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The output of a heating system.
examples: During the power outage we had no heat because the controls are electric.   Older folks like more heat than the young.

entries.meaning: (countable) A violent action unintermitted; a single effort.

description: From Middle English heten, from Old English hǣtan (“to heat; become hot”), from Proto-Germanic *haitijaną (“to heat, make hot”).

verbs.description: heat (third-person singular simple present heats, present participle heating, simple past and past participle heated or (dialectal) het)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause an increase in temperature of (an object or space); to cause to become hot (often with "up").
(intransitive) To become hotter.
examples: There's a pot of soup heating on the stove.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To excite or make hot by action or emotion; to make feverish.
(transitive, figurative) To excite ardour in; to rouse to action; to excite to excess; to inflame, as the passions.
(transitive, slang) To arouse, to excite (sexually).
